Sleepless in Schenectady? 4 ways it hurts family finances Use your key for the next article Comment Play Sleep deprivation is the condition of not having enough sleep; it can be either chronic or acute. Dr. Steve shares six ways to sleep better each night. on.aol.com 
"Early to bed, early to rise makes a man healthy, wealthy and wise," said Benjamin Franklin a few centuries ago. Capital Region families may well know this saying from school...but its relevance today is stronger than ever. Sleep or lack of it can more than just ruin a person's day. It can compound financial crises. Photo by Peter Macdiarmid/Getty Images 
People who are perpetually sleep deprived have less self-control than their more well-rested counterparts. People who often get too little sleep also report lower well-being and poorer financial decision making. 
Four ways sleep negatively affects financial decisions: Less self-control. Good sleep is linked to better mental functioning, including self-control â€“ a key to financial well-being. Self-control helps you make better financial decisions by allowing you to consider both the short-term and long-term benefits of any decision (like using credit cards). False optimism . In a recent study, an MRI was used to study brain activity after participants lost a night of sleep and were put in gambling situations. The result: increased activity in brain areas that determine positive outcomes, and decreased activity in areas leading to negative outcomes. So, lack of sleep can cause us to feel overly optimistic about the choices we make, for example, whether or not we can actually afford something. ( www.moneytalksnews.com , February 5, 2015) Increased physical illness , Insufficient sleep can also cost you in increased medical expenses: it is linked to the development of chronic diseases and conditions including diabetes, cardiovascular disease, obesity, and depression. Chronic mental fatigue. Lack of sleep drains the body of energy. Most likely just getting through the workday is all people can accomplish. Paying bills that are due or cooking a nutritious meal at home can yield to a night of TV and fast food from McDonald's. 
Are you getting enough sleep? The National Sleep Foundation recommends that adults (26-64 years) get 7-9 hours per night. Making sure you get enough sleep can improve your financial well-being!
